name: Madame Tussauds London
summary: The definition of a global tourist trap. Expensive tickets (£35+) for a crowded walkthrough of wax figures that often look nothing like the celebrities. Locals actively avoid this area.

red_flags.evidence: "Over £100 for a family to see motionless dolls... absolute robbery." (TripAdvisor)
"You are shuffled through like cattle, barely time for a photo." (Reddit)

positive_signals.evidence: "My 10-year-old loved the Marvel 4D experience." (Mumsnet)

sample_reviews.text: Complete waste of money. Spend your time at the free museums in London instead.
It was busy but fun to take selfies with the Royal Family figures.

embedding_text: Madame Tussauds London in London, UK. attraction. tourist_trap. Expensive tickets (£35+) for a crowded walkthrough of wax figures. Locals avoid. Red flags: Exorbitant price for wax dolls, Overcrowded conveyor belt. Positives: Good for young children.

name: Hard Rock Cafe Times Square
summary: Generic, overpriced burgers served in a loud, corporate environment. You pay a premium for the location and the memorabilia on the walls, with food quality comparable to a fast-food chain.

red_flags.evidence: "Eating here in NYC is like going to Italy and eating Pizza Hut." (Eater NY)
"$22 for a burger that tastes like it was frozen 6 months ago." (Yelp)

positive_signals.evidence: "Cool to see the Beatles' suits, even if the food was bad." (TripAdvisor)

sample_reviews.text: Please, I beg you, walk two blocks to a real restaurant. This is a factory.
Great atmosphere and loud music! The service was slow but we expected that.

embedding_text: Hard Rock Cafe Times Square in New York, USA. restaurant. tourist_trap. Generic, overpriced burgers in a corporate environment. You pay for location and memorabilia. Red flags: Zero local connection, Mediocre food at premium prices. Positives: Music memorabilia.

name: Checkpoint Charlie
summary: Historically significant location reduced to a tacky photo-op. The booth is a replica, and until recently, actors dressed as soldiers would aggressively demand money for photos. It's surrounded by cheap souvenir shops selling fake gas masks.

red_flags.evidence: "The actors were banned for harassing tourists for cash, but the vibe remains scams-y." (Berlin News)
"It's a small shed in the middle of a street... underwhelming and fake." (Reddit)

positive_signals.evidence: "The outdoor display boards and the nearby Haus am Checkpoint Charlie museum are actually educational." (Lonely Planet)

sample_reviews.text: Just a hut in the road. Go to the Berlin Wall Memorial instead for real history.
Crowded but you have to see it once if you are in Berlin.

embedding_text: Checkpoint Charlie in Berlin, Germany. attraction. tourist_trap. Historically significant location reduced to a tacky photo-op with a replica booth. Surrounded by souvenir shops. Red flags: Disneyfication of history, Aggressive touts. Positives: Museum nearby is good.

name: Manneken Pis
summary: A tiny (61cm) statue of a peeing boy that draws massive crowds of tourists. It is notoriously difficult to see through the wall of selfie sticks, and visitors are almost universally disappointed by its size.

red_flags.evidence: "It is shockingly small. You fight through 500 people to see a garden gnome." (Reddit)
"Watch your wallet. The crowd is a playground for thieves." (Local Police Warning)

positive_signals.evidence: "It's fun when they dress him up in different outfits." (TripAdvisor)

sample_reviews.text: Walked past it without realizing. It's tiny. Go for the waffles nearby, not the statue.
The ultimate Brussels prank on tourists. We locals laugh at the crowds.

embedding_text: Manneken Pis in Brussels, Belgium. attraction. tourist_trap. Tiny (61cm) statue of a peeing boy. Draws massive crowds, notoriously difficult to see, and underwhelming. Red flags: Underwhelming and crowded, Pickpocket hotspot. Positives: Funny costumes.

name: Hofbräuhaus München
summary: The world's most famous beer hall. It is loud, chaotic, and dominated by tourists, but the beer is fresh, the history is genuine (founded 1589), and the live Oompah music delivers the expected Bavarian atmosphere.

red_flags.evidence: "Waiters are rude and you have to fight for a table." (TripAdvisor)
"The pork knuckle was dry. You come here for beer, not the food." (Food Blog)

positive_signals.evidence: "Despite the tourists, the painted ceilings and brass band are the real deal." (Rick Steves)
"1 liter of beer is standard Munich price, not a rip-off." (Reddit)

sample_reviews.text: It's a tourist trap but a fun one. Drink the beer, listen to the band, eat somewhere else.
Noisy, rude staff, and food was cold. Augustiner Keller is much better.

embedding_text: Hofbräuhaus München in Munich, Germany. restaurant. mixed. World's most famous beer hall. Loud, chaotic, dominated by tourists. Beer is fresh and history is genuine, but food is average. Red flags: Aggressive service, Average canteen food. Positives: Historic atmosphere, Fair beer prices.

name: Tim Ho Wan (Sham Shui Po)
summary: Famous as the 'cheapest Michelin-starred restaurant in the world'. While they have expanded globally, the original locations in HK still serve incredible BBQ pork buns for a few dollars. It's crowded, but the quality-to-price ratio is undeniable.

red_flags.evidence: "They want you to eat and leave. Tables are shared." (OpenRice)

positive_signals.evidence: "The baked BBQ pork buns are a masterpiece of texture and flavor." (Michelin Guide)
"Michelin quality for the price of a McDonald's meal." (Travel Blog)

sample_reviews.text: The queue moves fast. The pork buns are life changing. Don't expect luxury, expect flavor.
Standard quality compared to other HK dim sum places, but the price is good.

embedding_text: Tim Ho Wan (Sham Shui Po) in Hong Kong. restaurant. local_gem. Cheapest Michelin-starred restaurant in the world. Incredible BBQ pork buns for a few dollars. Crowded but high quality-to-price ratio. Red flags: Rushed service. Positives: World-class Dim Sum, Incredibly cheap.

name: Hawker Chan (Chinatown Complex)
summary: The original stall that won a Michelin star (and later lost it). Locals are divided; some respect the legacy, while many argue the quality dropped after expansion and that there are better soy sauce chicken stalls in the same hawker center.

red_flags.evidence: "Since franchising, the chicken is often dry and the sauce less complex." (DaniFoodings)
"Tourists queue here; locals go to Emerald Soy Sauce Chicken two rows down." (Reddit)

positive_signals.evidence: "For $3-5 SGD, it is still a very good meal." (SethLui.com)

sample_reviews.text: It's good, but not mind-blowing. The star was for the price, not because it's the best chicken in SG.
Worth the wait to try the famous chicken. Skin was crispy and sauce was sweet.

embedding_text: Hawker Chan (Chinatown Complex) in Singapore. street_food. mixed. Original stall that won a Michelin star. Locals divided, arguing quality dropped after expansion and better options exist nearby. Red flags: Mass expansion issues, Better options nearby. Positives: Still very affordable.

name: Pastéis de Belém
summary: The birthplace of the pastel de nata. Despite the constant line of tourists, this is a legitimate institution. The tarts are served warm, the recipe is secret, and they are distinctively different (and often considered better) than competitors.

red_flags.evidence: "The line looks terrifying, but it moves very fast." (Lonely Planet)

positive_signals.evidence: "Crispier crust and creamier filling than any other nata in Lisbon." (Serious Eats)
"Even locals admit these are the gold standard, though we usually buy them to-go." (Reddit)

sample_reviews.text: I thought it was hype, but they really are different. The pastry is salty and crispy. Incredible.
Don't queue for a table, just go to the 'take away' counter inside. Best with cinnamon.

embedding_text: Pastéis de Belém in Lisbon, Portugal. cafe. local_gem. Birthplace of the pastel de nata. Despite tourist crowds, the tarts are served warm and considered the gold standard. Red flags: Always crowded. Positives: Unique recipe, Locals respect it.

name: Mercado de San Miguel
summary: A stunning iron-glass market that has transformed into a high-end tapas food court. The food is high quality, but the prices are double the city average and the clientele is 100% tourists. It's a 'Gourmet Trap'.

red_flags.evidence: "€15 for a gin tonic and €4 for a single oyster is not normal Madrid pricing." (Madrid Food Tour)
"Locals don't buy groceries here anymore, it's strictly for visitors." (Reddit)

positive_signals.evidence: "Everything is delicious and looks beautiful, even if you overpay." (The Infatuation)
"A feast for the eyes." (Lonely Planet)

sample_reviews.text: Go for photos and maybe one drink, then go to La Latina for real tapas.
Expensive but convenient to try many things in one place.

embedding_text: Mercado de San Miguel in Madrid, Spain. market. mixed. Stunning iron-glass market turned high-end tapas food court. High quality food but prices are double the average and 100% tourists. Red flags: Inflated prices, No locals shop here. Positives: High quality variety, Beautiful architecture.

name: Pat's King of Steaks
summary: The inventor of the cheesesteak, famous for its rivalry with Geno's across the street. While historic, the steak is often described as gristly and unseasoned compared to local favorites like Dalessandro's or John's Roast Pork.

red_flags.evidence: "Meat was chopped too coarse and was dry. Purely running on fame." (Philly Eater)
"No one from Philly eats at Pat's or Geno's. Those are for tourists." (Reddit)

positive_signals.evidence: "You have to respect the history of where it started." (Bon Appetit)

sample_reviews.text: Tourist hype. Go to Dalessandro's or Ishkabibble's.
I loved the 'Whiz Wit' experience! The line was fun.

embedding_text: Pat's King of Steaks in Philadelphia, USA. street_food. tourist_trap. Inventor of the cheesesteak. Historic, but steak is often gristly and unseasoned compared to local favorites. Red flags: Resting on laurels, Locals go elsewhere. Positives: The original.

name: teamLab Planets
summary: An immersive digital art museum where you walk barefoot through water and crystal lights. While it is incredibly popular on Instagram, the sensory experience is genuinely unique and technically impressive, earning praise from art lovers and selfie-seekers alike.

red_flags.evidence: "Packed with influencers blocking the path for photos." (Japan Guide)

positive_signals.evidence: "Walking through the knee-deep water projection is unlike anything else." (TimeOut Tokyo)
"Despite crowds, the flow is managed perfectly." (TripAdvisor)

sample_reviews.text: I thought it would be a gimmick, but it was actually magical. The flower room is stunning.
A bit smelly in the locker room (feet), but the art is cool.

embedding_text: teamLab Planets in Tokyo, Japan. attraction. local_gem. Immersive digital art museum. Incredibly popular on Instagram, but the sensory experience (barefoot, water) is genuinely unique and technically impressive. Red flags: High tourist density. Positives: Unique sensory experience, Well organized.

name: Señor Frog's
summary: The epitome of the spring break tourist trap. Overpriced, sugary drinks served in yard glasses, balloon hats, and conga lines. The food is afterthought Tex-Mex, and the entire business model is based on getting tourists drunk enough to ignore the bill.

red_flags.evidence: "$20 for a margarita made with cheap mix and barely any tequila." (TripAdvisor)
"You could be in Vegas or Florida. Nothing Mexican about it." (Travel Blog)

positive_signals.evidence: "If you want to get wasted and dance on tables, this is the place." (Reddit)

sample_reviews.text: Fun for 20 minutes until you see the bill. Hidden service charges everywhere.
Avoid. Go to downtown Cancun (Parque de las Palapas) for real food.

embedding_text: Señor Frog's in Cancun, Mexico. bar. tourist_trap. Epitome of spring break trap. Overpriced sugary drinks, balloon hats, and conga lines. Food is afterthought Tex-Mex. Red flags: Expensive bad drinks, Artificial atmosphere. Positives: Party vibe.

name: Franklin Barbecue
summary: Famous for 4-hour lines that start at 7 AM. While it attracts tourists worldwide, it is NOT a trap. The brisket is widely considered the best in the known universe, and the 'line culture' is a social event with free beer and chairs.

red_flags.evidence: "You have to commit half a day to lunch." (Eater Austin)

positive_signals.evidence: "The fat renders into something like meat candy. It lives up to the hype." (Texas Monthly)
"The line is a tailgate party. Everyone is happy." (Reddit)

sample_reviews.text: I hate lines. I hate hype. But I ate this brisket and I understood everything.
Sold out by 1pm. Get there early or don't bother.

embedding_text: Franklin Barbecue in Austin, USA. restaurant. local_gem. Famous for 4-hour lines. Not a trap; brisket is considered best in the world. Line culture is a social event. Red flags: The Wait. Positives: Best brisket globally, Fun waiting experience.

name: Schwartz's Deli
summary: The oldest deli in Canada, serving Montreal Smoked Meat. It is cramped, cash-only, and always has a line, but the product (cured for 10 days, hand-sliced) is unique to the city and superior to tourist-focused competitors.

red_flags.evidence: "You are elbow-to-elbow with strangers. Not for claustrophobes." (TripAdvisor)
"Bring cash or use their ATM with high fees." (Google Maps)

positive_signals.evidence: "The medium-fat sandwich melts in your mouth. Unmatched." (Montreal Eater)
"No menu changes, no renovations. Pure history." (Globe and Mail)

sample_reviews.text: Get the cherry coke and a medium fat sandwich. Don't ask for a menu. Best in the world.
The line is annoying but you can buy the meat at the takeout door next to it.

embedding_text: Schwartz's Deli in Montreal, Canada. restaurant. local_gem. Oldest deli in Canada. Cramped, cash-only, always a line. Smoked meat (cured 10 days) is unique and superior to competitors. Red flags: Cramped communal seating, Cash only. Positives: Iconic meat quality, Unchanged since 1928.

name: Café Sacher (Hotel Sacher)
summary: Home of the world's most famous chocolate cake. The setting is opulent and historic, but many visitors (and food critics) find the cake itself dry and overrated compared to the moister version at Café Demel.

red_flags.evidence: "The cake is notoriously dry. You are paying for the brand, not the taste." (Serious Eats)
"Waited 45 mins in the cold for a slice of cake." (TripAdvisor)

positive_signals.evidence: "It is the original. The interior is stunningly Viennese." (Lonely Planet)
"Feels like stepping back into the empire." (Travel Blog)

sample_reviews.text: Go to Demel instead. Sacher is dry and touristy. Demel is where the locals go.
It's a bucket list item. The coffee was great, the cake was... okay.

embedding_text: Café Sacher in Vienna, Austria. cafe. mixed. Home of famous Sacher Torte. Opulent and historic setting, but cake is often considered dry and overrated compared to Café Demel. Red flags: Dry cake, Queues. Positives: The original location, Elegant atmosphere.

name: Pike Place Chowder
summary: A rare spot that is both a massive tourist trap (lines wrapping around the block) AND a culinary award winner. The chowder is legitimately Hall-of-Fame level, but locals often avoid it due to the crowds, opting to order ahead or go to their second location.

red_flags.evidence: "Line is 45 minutes minimum on a weekend." (Seattle Times)

positive_signals.evidence: "The clam chowder has won more awards than any other in the nation." (Food Network)
"Creamy, loaded with clams, perfect sourdough bowl." (Yelp)

sample_reviews.text: Pro tip: Order online for pickup and skip the line. Chowder is legit.
Good chowder but not worth waiting an hour in the rain.

embedding_text: Pike Place Chowder in Seattle, USA. restaurant. mixed. Massive tourist trap with long lines, but the chowder is legitimately Hall-of-Fame level. Locals order ahead or go to second location. Red flags: Insane lines. Positives: Award winning food, Consistent quality.

name: Anne Frank House
summary: A profoundly moving historical site. While getting tickets is stressful (they sell out weeks in advance), the museum itself is respectful, well-curated, and absolutely essential. It resists commercialization inside.

red_flags.evidence: "If you don't book 6 weeks out, you aren't getting in." (Rick Steves)

positive_signals.evidence: "The empty rooms speak louder than any exhibit. A deeply emotional experience." (Guardian)
"Banning photos keeps the atmosphere solemn and respectful." (TripAdvisor)

sample_reviews.text: It's not a 'fun' attraction, but it's the most important thing to do in Amsterdam.
The ticket system is a nightmare, but once you are in, it is powerful.

embedding_text: Anne Frank House in Amsterdam, Netherlands. attraction. local_gem. Profoundly moving historical site. Tickets sell out weeks in advance, but the museum is respectful, well-curated, and essential. Red flags: Impossible ticketing. Positives: Respectful and authentic, No photo policy.

name: La Sagrada Familia
summary: Gaudi's unfinished masterpiece is the most visited site in Spain, yet it defies the 'trap' label due to its sheer architectural brilliance. The interior light show is spiritual, and the audio guide is excellent.

red_flags.evidence: "Always packed. Book the earliest slot to breathe." (Lonely Planet)

positive_signals.evidence: "There is nothing else like it on earth. The stained glass effect is blindingly beautiful." (Architecture Digest)
"Your ticket literally pays for the building to be finished." (Official Site)

sample_reviews.text: I thought I'd hate it because of the crowds. I cried. It's spectacular.
Skip the towers (claustrophobic and not worth extra cost), but the basilica is a must.

embedding_text: La Sagrada Familia in Barcelona, Spain. attraction. local_gem. Gaudi's unfinished masterpiece. Defies 'trap' label due to sheer architectural brilliance. Interior light show is spiritual. Red flags: Crowds. Positives: Architectural wonder, Ticket funds construction.

name: Tsukiji Outer Market
summary: The famous wholesale auction moved to Toyosu, but the 'Outer Market' remains. It is now 100% focused on tourists with overpriced Wagyu skewers and strawberry mochi. However, the sushi quality in the sit-down restaurants remains very high.

red_flags.evidence: "¥4000 for a crab leg is robbery. They prey on confusion." (Tokyo Cheapo)
"You can't walk. It's a crush of bodies." (Reddit)

positive_signals.evidence: "The sushi restaurants tucked away in alleys still get the best catch." (Sushi Blog)

sample_reviews.text: It's a theme park now. Go to Ameyoko market for cheaper street food.
Expensive but the Tamagoyaki (egg omelet) on a stick was delicious.

embedding_text: Tsukiji Outer Market in Tokyo, Japan. market. mixed. Wholesale market moved, leaving a tourist-focused zone. Overpriced street food (Wagyu skewers). Sushi quality in sit-down restaurants remains high. Red flags: Street food markup, Overcrowded. Positives: Fresh fish availability.

name: Café Tortoni
summary: The oldest cafe in Argentina (1858). While it has a line of tourists down the block and mediocre churros, the interior remains a stunning example of Belle Époque architecture and a cultural landmark.

red_flags.evidence: "Waited an hour. The churros were cold." (TripAdvisor)
"Coffee is burnt. You are there for the photos." (Local Guide)

positive_signals.evidence: "The stained glass and marble tables are breathtaking." (Architectural Digest)

sample_reviews.text: Skip the line, go to Las Violetas instead. Better food, same vibe.
Beautiful place to sit and imagine Borges writing. Service was old school.

embedding_text: Café Tortoni in Buenos Aires, Argentina. cafe. mixed. Oldest cafe in Argentina (1858). Long tourist lines and mediocre food, but the Belle Époque interior is stunning and culturally significant. Red flags: Long queues, Food is secondary. Positives: Historic interior.

name: Tacos El Califa de León
summary: Recently awarded a Michelin star, this tiny stand has only four items on the menu (steak tacos). There is no seating, the meat quality is exceptional, and despite the new fame, it remains a gritty, authentic experience.

red_flags.evidence: "You eat standing up next to a hot grill. It's intense." (Eater)

positive_signals.evidence: " The Gaonera taco is so tender you don't even need teeth." (Michelin Guide)
"No sides, no drinks, just meat and tortillas made fresh." (Culinary Backstreets)

sample_reviews.text: Simple perfection. The red sauce is spicy! Don't be scared by the neighborhood.
Pricey for a taco ($5 USD) but the quality is undeniable.

embedding_text: Tacos El Califa de León in Mexico City, Mexico. street_food. local_gem. Michelin-starred tiny stand with only four items. No seating, exceptional meat quality. Gritty, authentic experience. Red flags: No seating/amenities. Positives: Michelin quality meat, Pure focus on product.

name: Ben's Chili Bowl
summary: A civil rights landmark on U Street famous for its Half-Smoke. While culturally essential to DC history, many locals admit the food is greasy and heavy, and better chili exists elsewhere. You go for the history, not the gastronomy.

red_flags.evidence: "The chili is mostly grease and salt. It's nostalgia food." (Washington Post comment)

positive_signals.evidence: "It survived the riots. It fed MLK. It's holy ground." (Eater DC)
"At 2am, nothing beats a half-smoke." (Reddit)

sample_reviews.text: Bill Cosby is off the wall, but Obama is on it. Food is mediocre, vibe is 10/10.
Classic DC experience. The half-smoke was spicy and messy.

embedding_text: Ben's Chili Bowl in Washington DC, USA. restaurant. mixed. Civil rights landmark famous for Half-Smoke. Culturally essential, but food is greasy and heavy. You go for history, not gastronomy. Red flags: Greasy/Average food. Positives: Black history landmark, Late night staple.

name: Voodoo Doughnut
summary: Famous for long lines, pink boxes, and donuts topped with cereal or bacon. It is the definition of an 'Instagram Trap'. Locals almost universally prefer Blue Star or Pip's, citing Voodoo's stale dough and reliance on shock value toppings.

red_flags.evidence: "Friends don't let friends eat Voodoo. Go to Blue Star." (Reddit)
"Donuts were dry, clearly made hours ago. Just sugar overload." (Willamette Week)

positive_signals.evidence: "The voodoo doll donut is cute for a photo." (TripAdvisor)

sample_reviews.text: Waited 45 mins for a stale donut with Fruit Loops on it. Never again.
It's a Portland rite of passage. Just go once for the weirdness.

embedding_text: Voodoo Doughnut in Portland, USA. cafe. tourist_trap. Famous for pink boxes and cereal toppings. 'Instagram Trap'. Locals prefer Blue Star, citing stale dough and reliance on shock value. Red flags: Locals hate it, Stale/Dry product. Positives: Fun branding.

name: Lau Pa Sat (Satay Street)
summary: A historic Victorian structure in the financial district. At night, the street closes for 'Satay Street'. It is undeniably atmospheric and the satay is tasty, but prices are 20-30% higher than neighborhood hawker centers and aggressive touts can be annoying.

red_flags.evidence: "You pay for the location. East Coast Lagoon has cheaper/better satay." (Honeycombers)
"Stall owners will push 'sets' on you that cost more than individual sticks." (TripAdvisor)

positive_signals.evidence: "Eating satay on the street surrounded by skyscrapers is a vibe." (TimeOut Singapore)
"The satay is consistently good, charred and smoky." (LadyIronChef)

sample_reviews.text: Great atmosphere but watch out for the 'set menu' upsell. Just order sticks.
A bit pricey for hawker food, but clean and beautiful.

embedding_text: Lau Pa Sat in Singapore. market. mixed. Historic structure, famous for Satay Street at night. Atmospheric and tasty, but prices are higher than neighborhood centers and touts are aggressive. Red flags: Tourist pricing, Aggressive selling. Positives: Unique atmosphere, Reliable food.

name: The Venetian Gondolas
summary: A motorized boat ride through an indoor shopping mall with a painted sky. The gondoliers sing (often beautifully), but the experience is short, expensive ($39/person), and entirely artificial.

red_flags.evidence: "It's a boat in a chlorinated pool inside a mall. Tacky." (Reddit)
"Ride lasted 12 minutes. Almost $40 per person. Do the math." (TripAdvisor)

positive_signals.evidence: "Cheesy but my girlfriend loved the singing." (Yelp)

sample_reviews.text: Overpriced mall ride. You are being watched by shoppers eating gelato.
The singer was actually talented. Good for a laugh.

embedding_text: The Venetian Gondolas in Las Vegas, USA. attraction. tourist_trap. Motorized boat ride through an indoor mall. Gondoliers sing, but experience is short, expensive ($39/person), and artificial. Red flags: Fake Venice, Short duration. Positives: Romantic cliche.
